results.title: Faces
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Walter Reade Organization
results.brief_description: Faces concentrates on two scenarios, one where middle-aged businessmen cheat on their wives and the other where the wives bring home a younger man from a nightclub. Both wives and husbands take turns in testing the novelty of the situations, initially improvising to bridge the awkwardness but then risking more and more. While the night out feels liberating, it ends up tearing painfully at their conservative personas.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Walter Reade Organization

results.title: Skeletons aren't scary
results.creator_credit: John Dick, Bosisto Productions and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Using muppets and animated sequences, this film deals with the death of a children’s cat and the feelings and emotions that are associated with death and dying.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Dick, Bosisto Productions and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Mean streets
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Jonathan Taplin and Taplin-Perry-Scorsese Productions
results.brief_description: Scorsese drew on his own childhood and adolescence (Harvey Keitel is his alter ego) in depicting the macho world of small time crime in New York’s Little Italy. He achieves a certain psychological distance from the obsessions of growing up Catholic in a society structured by contradictions and rituals. The loose, jagged structure contains an extraordinary blend of the operatic (the film has been described as a kind of rock opera) and the naturalistic (there was a good deal of improvisation by the actors). The effect of the lighting in bars and streets takes the film to the edge of expressionism; the hand held, rapidly tracking camera amplifies the sense of emotional and physical violence. Much of the film was actually shot in Los Angeles. Cast also includes David Proval, Amy Robinson and Richard Romanus.

results.title: Shadows
results.creator_credit: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Cassavetes, McEndree, Cassel Productions
results.brief_description: ‘Shadows’ was a vanguard work of the independent American cinema, a bittersweet comedy centred on three African-American outsiders - Lelia and his two jazz-musicians brothers living in Greenwich Village - two of whom pass for white and all are part of the late fifties ‘lost generation’. We follow Lelia through three brief romantic involvements. Although the film was recognised at the time for its treatment of race, Cassavetes saw this as incidental to the wider question of identity. His special commitment to expression through performance and a concomitant openness of form give his films a rough, uninflected, anecdotal quality (a form of ‘fictional cinema verite’). ‘Shadows’, like other Cassavetes’ films was fully scripted despite the reference in the end title to the film as ‘an improvisation’. Cast includes Lelia Goldoni, Ben Carruthers, Hugh Hurd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Cassavetes, Maurice McEndree and Cassavetes, McEndree, Cassel Productions

results.title: DoDo helps Interpol
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor, Joseph E. Levine, Robert Maxwell, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo helps Interpol catch card cheats on an ocean liner. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: Dodo's arrival story
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor, Joseph E. Levine, Robert Maxwell, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 41 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode the whole gang have a party to celebrate DoDo’s first anniversary on Earth, but, when DoDo is asked to recall how he came to Earth, his account provokes a conflict of memories. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: Professor Finger builds a bridge
results.creator_credit: Joseph E. Levine, Robert Maxwell, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
Dodo and the bird come to the rescue of the Professor when his new inventions of a plastic bridge over a ravine cannot take the stress. The remains of the bridge become a ferry instead.

results.title: Design for today
results.creator_credit: Hugh Hudson, David Cammell, Lionel Hoare, Associated British-Pathe and Cammell Hudson
results.brief_description: An unintentionally hilarious promotional film becomes an involuntary instrument of social critism. Produced to promote the virtues of British design, the film chronicles a catalogue of constructed environmental features which all manifest a brutalising austerity. Park-O-Matics, Mini-Mokes and nuclear reactors become the indices of the sterile, proto-human coherance of consumer society. No narration; instead the film employs a great and swinging cocktail jazz score by UK session man, Johnny Scott.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh Hudson, David Cammell, Lionel Hoare, Associated British-Pathe and Cammell Hudson

results.title: A Life less ordinary
results.creator_credit: Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald and Figment Films
results.brief_description: Acclaimed “Trainspotting” trio (director Danny Boyle, producer Andrew Macdonald, and screenwriter John Hodge) re-unite for this wacky romantic comedy. Two angels, O’Reilly (Holly Hunter) and Jackson (Delroy Lindo) are assigned to make two people fall in love. If they fail the angels will be stuck on earth forever. The targets of this matchmaking mission are Celine (Cameron Diaz), a heartless, rich woman with a penchant for guns, and Robert (Ewan McGregor), an aspiring pulp novelist who works as a janitor in the corporation owned by Celine’s father (Ian Holm). When Robert is sacked and replaced by a robot a chain of events begins which brings the two together. Robert attempts to kidnap Celine and get his job back, and Celine attempts to make Robert extort money from her father. Meanwhile angels O’Reilly and Jackson are working overtime to get Robert and Celine to fall in love, which isn’t easy seeing as the two mismatched kidnappers create chaos wherever they go. A quirky adventure romance, “A Life less ordinary” races along with a great soundtrack and moments of pure madness and fantasy (look out for the song and dance routine between Ewan McGregor and Cameron Diaz).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald and Figment Films

Robert attempts to kidnap Celine and get his job back, and Celine attempts to make Robert extort money from her father. Meanwhile angels O’Reilly and Jackson are working overtime to get Robert and Celine to fall in love, which isn’t easy seeing as the two mismatched kidnappers create chaos wherever they go. A quirky adventure romance, “A Life less ordinary” races along with a great soundtrack and moments of pure madness and fantasy (look out for the song and dance routine between Ewan McGregor and Cameron Diaz).

results.title: Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: Shekhar Kapur, Alison Owen, Eric Fellner, Tim Bevan, Jill Bilcock and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: Elizabeth begins during the tense period before Elizabeth I became Queen of England. She is a young vivacious girl thrust suddenly into the machiavellian world of politics when she is tried for treason at the age of 21. Surviving this she becomes Queen, and the film charts the beginning of her reign as she struggles to learn the skills of a monarch. Cate Blanchett is amazing as a young woman who slowly casts off her youth and becomes the legendary Virgin Queen that ruled the Elizabethan age. Shekhar Kapur’s film manages to be both entertaining and historically insightful. Lavish costumes and an excellent cast make this compelling viewing. The cast also includes Joseph Fiennes as Elizabeth’s lover Lord Robert Dudley, Richard Attenborough as Sir William Cecil, and Geoffrey Rush as her political adviser Sir Francis Walsingham. (Awards: Cate Blanchett won the 1998 Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Drama, and “Elizabeth” won the 1998 Academy Award for Best Makeup)
